title:
Curiosity-Driven Science: The in Situ Jungle Biomechanics Lab in the
  Amazon Rainforest

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Field work is an essential component not just for organismal biology, but also for the expanding umbrella of disciplines which have turned their attention towards living systems. Observing organisms in naturalistic contexts is a critical component of discovery; however, conducting field research can be a massive barrier for scientists who do not have experience working with organisms in a naturalistic context under challenging field conditions. Here we propose 8 critical steps for organizing and executing interdisciplinary curiosity-driven field research, drawing on the insights from The in Situ Jungle Biomechanics Lab (JBL). The JBL program is a field research course that helps early-career scientists gain experience in organizing and conducting interdisciplinary field research. JBL uses a curiosity-driven approach to field science education by encouraging early-career researchers to explore scientific questions in the Peruvian Amazon with a non-prescriptive approach to research output. We achieve an inclusive research space by bringing scientists from across disciplines together, with local communities to collaborate and spark new questions and ideas. To stoke curiosity, the JBL imparts a naturalist tradition set forth by organismal biologists of the $20^{\text {th }}$ century who have extolled the merits of observing the natural world as a form of scientific exploration.


Keywords: field research, curiosity-driven science, biodiversity, scientific education, in situ studies, environmental identity

## SIGNIFICANCE STATEMENT

The in Situ Jungle Biomechanics Lab brings early career scientists together in the Peruvian Amazon rainforest to conduct high-level, curiosity-driven interdisciplinary science. Here, we provide several steps on how to build an in situ approach to field research which emphasizes the environment, the scientific community, and the broader community where field stations exist. Creating space for curiosity-driven field research, especially for early career researchers, will have long-term impacts on the organismal biophysics community.

# INTRODUCTION "The urge to explore, it is argued, like the ability to discover, can be developed"
-Thomas Eisner [1]. While often not considered in the traditional teachings of the scientific method, curiosity is a potent driver of scientific investigation. Curiosity is the stimulant that keeps eyes peeled to scan the natural world and the organisms that inhabit it. Curiosity is also the catalyst that converts observation, the first step of scientific inquiry, into a testable hypothesis, the functional unit of discovery. While indispensable for scientific learning [2, 3, 4, 5], curiosity is not often enough the focus of the scientific curriculum [6]. Is it then possible to make curiosity the focal point of a biological field course? Here we present a field guide of sorts for promoting curiosity as a key factor in biological field research. We use lessons learned from the implementation of the in situ Jungle Biomechanics Lab (JBL) to inform this field guide on what we believe contributes to promoting curiosity in a field-course setting. The in Situ Jungle Biomechanics Laboratory (JBL) is an International Research Experience for Students (IRES) program funded by the U.S. National Science Foundation [7]. The goal of JBL is to provide early career researchers with the opportunity to engage in biological research under challenging field conditions in a part of the world where life is most diverse. The course selects early career researchers ranging from undergraduates to postdoctoral scholars and gives them the opportunity to develop a scientific project related to 'physics of life' and 'organismal biomechanics' (broadly defined [8]) in the Amazon rainforest, one of the world's most important biodiversity hotspots. Students collect data from living organisms and model their biomechanics through mathematical and robophysical models. Participants use accessible, open-source and frugal science tools such as portable high-speed cameras, DIY electronics, portable battery sources, and 3D-printers to make custom measurements and do science 'under a tree' (Figure 1) [9, 10, 11]. JBL aims to do for the rainforest what the Marine Biological Laboratory (MBL) does for marine systems, catalyzing discoveries at the interface of physics, biology, materials, robotics and engineering. JBL places curiosity-driven science at its center. Each participant engages in the field with a "learn by doing" philosophy, which allows students to explore biodiversity, ask questions, and collaborate among peers and with experienced program leaders to refine scientific questions and hypotheses. Curiosity, exploration, and inquiry then mature into an individually developed scientific project over the course of two weeks. Course participants also develop community outreach events with students ranging from elementary to undergraduate levels. What JBL aims to accomplish with its structure and implementation is an in situ approach to field science education. Here we use the term in situ similarly to its usage in education, indicating that in order to become curious about organisms, we must go to them to observe them where they have evolved, where they live, and where they interact with myriad other species. We, however, also think of the in situ approach as extending beyond the topic of organismal biology, involving the communities where the research takes place. JBL takes a holistic approach to field research education and places community engagement as a key component; curiosity can and should be shared. We have organized this essay in the form of a field guide which contains what we believe contributes to successfully centering curiosity-driven science in a field course. Curiosity is often the subject of study in childhood education [12, 13], but less so for scientific education later in life. We posit that an in situ approach to a field course can take the same principles that can encourage curiosity in early adolescence education and instill curiosity in early career researchers. Curiosity can then accelerate translation from ideas to innovative science and new discoveries-and that placing students in a novel environment during a field course is an excellent mechanism for fostering curiosity. We hope that what we have learned will provide kernels of insight for anyone in the biological sciences or otherwise who aims to develop field courses where curiosity is a central learning outcome. By no means do we think that we have created a singularly comprehensive solution for adding curiosity to scientific education for early-career researchers. We also by no means suggest that successful implementation of curiosity driven education requires teaching students in remote parts of the world as many of the lessons gleaned here are just as applicable to teaching curiosity in one's own back backyard. We do, however, want to emphasize the field site of the JBL, Finca las Piedras field station, as a means of also bringing attention to the critical role of biological field stations as a keystone for conservation, education, and sources of inspiration for early career researchers, especially in hyper-diverse ecosystems like the Amazon [14].

## 1 FIND A PLACE TO BE CURIOUS

Curiosity in field research requires a field in which to be curious. Here we use the term field in the loosest sense because a field for the biologist can mean many things. While the JBL field-site is the Amazon rainforest, a field may also be a literal field, a suburban backyard, or even the sewers of New York City [15].

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1. JBL course structure and FLP field site. A Structure of JBL beginning with applicant selection through the final stages of conducting research. B Aerial photograph of the Finca las Piedras (FLP) field station campus and its location in eastern Peru. C A student observing insects on the trunk of the tree in the Amazon Rainforest. D In situ curiosity-driven science 'under a tree' in the Amazon.

A bigger question than what is a field site is why field based research is an excellent opportunity to foster curiosity as a learning outcome. Curiosity is viewed as a state of information seeking [16], especially in the face of uncertainty [17]. We see the role of the "field site" as an uncertain environment which encourages course participants to explore what is under a log or nesting in the tree and promotes a constant state of information seeking that the more familiar classroom may not.

Biological field stations have long served as the field sites for early career researchers in life sciences [1]. Whether in the rainforest or the Arctic, field stations have provided scientists with a home base and resources to perform scientific observations or experiments for prolonged periods of time where it would otherwise not be possible. Therefore, while it may not be considered an explicit function of the field station, biological field stations have played a long-term role in promoting curiosity for researchers [1].

The field site for JBL, Finca las Piedras Field Station, is situated in the Amazonian rainforest in the Madre de Dios region of southeastern Peru (Figure 1). The station resides about an hour's drive away from the riverside town of Puerto Maldonado, the capital of the region. FLP Field Station itself is run and operated by the Alliance for a Sustainable Amazon (ASA), a non-profit organization committed to biodiversity conservation, providing education about, and facilitating research in the Peruvian Amazon. To date the ASA has reached more than 4,000 people from across the world and across age groups ranging from primary school students to doctoral students and even local elementary and high school teachers. Field sites are often the crossroads for students of the natural world from across generations, and are places of cross-pollination of ideas and inspiration among generations of scientists.

For the JBL specifically, Finca las Piedras is a field site that matches the mission of the field course. FLP is home to more than 3,400 documented species on-site (surely with many thousands more yet undocumented). Scientists are likely to encounter arboreal snakes, burrowing tarantulas, aquatic caiman, and a dizzying variety of other animals and plants on a single excursion onto the well-maintained trail system. Naturalists and project staff at the station are experts on how, where and when to find the specific organisms participants are interested in finding. Finca las Piedras also has electricity provided by solar panels and gasoline generators that are necessary to run lighting or high-speed cameras, needs that are specific to conducting biomechanics research. This affords a wide breadth of freedom in terms of the projects they can undertake and questions they can ask, which are two of the primary considerations for

designing the JBL. It is a critical consideration for any field course to ensure that your chosen field site, whether a long-standing field station or a backyard, matches the needs of both your course goals and participants.

# 2 PREPARING FOR CURIOSITY: CARCENIZATION BEFORE SPECIALIZATION 

No two field courses are the same, and no two field courses have the exact same needs. However, for implementing a field course, we take on a philosophy that places carcenization before specialization. Carcenization is the "crabification" of an organisms body plan. For crustaceans specifically, an evolutionary trajectory towards the body plan of a crab has proven time and time again to be a winning strategy. The carcenization, or crab-ification, of an organism has occurred at least five times [18], and is the phylogenetic embodiment of "if it ain't broke, don't fix it." The crab body plan, a flattened round carapace and the ability to scuttle quickly along the ground, tends to be a good enough solution for life in the depths, life on a reef, or even life up in the mountains [19]. Preparation for a field course can take a note from crabs; a few core features contribute to success in a wide range of environments and from those core features it is easier to make a more field-specific and specialized field course.

Preparation for safety is foundational to promoting curiosity in the field and should be a first consideration. Safety preparation can vary widely among field sites, and field sites can vary greatly in their access to emergency medical care. Critically, any plan for a field course should also be cognizant that safety risks can vary among individuals from different backgrounds and identities [20]. As an organizer for any fieldwork, you should include a Risk Management Plan document which outlines basic expectations for safe conduct, operating procedures for an emergency, etc. Here, we have included an example from the JBL as a template and resource (S1).

In addition to safety, a strong fieldwork plan lays out detailed logistics regarding travel. A local field course may only need a carpool sign-up sheet to ensure equitable access among participants. Organizing and leading field course farther away than a short drive is significantly more complicated and can be more constrained by a budget. With dates established, a detailed timeline is critical for preparation. It is also necessary to understand local laws and what permits will be necessary to conduct work or collect biological specimens at any given field site. Other small details regarding travel can have large impacts on success, especially with respect to transporting equipment and reagents. While seemingly obvious at first, specific details around travel logistics can get lost in early preparation steps, and we recommend having an explicit travel plan that outlines how each participant will get to the field site, which elements each person is responsible for, and a backup plan in case something should impede travel.

Safety and travel form the preparation fundamentals for any field course and are first-order priorities regardless of where a fieldwork takes place. Returning to our analogy of crabs, there is, however, another hypothesis for why carcenization is such a winning strategy. It is not just that the crab-like form handles most of life's challenges, but also that the crab body plan is a great canvas to evolve specialized anatomical structures [18, 21]. We think a preparation strategy that has the best likelihood of success is one that places carcenization before specialization. A strategy that builds a strong, detailed logistical foundation will facilitate more technical and specialized research. For a field course that emphasizes organismal biomechanics, some key considerations are electrical access and transporting dozens of kilograms of cameras and optical equipment. However, even if none of the equipment made it to the field site, it would still be possible to successfully do curiosity-driven science without specialized equipment. Many phenomenal discoveries come from close observation with minimal scientific equipment [22]. Our mindset is that a successful field course is one that gets all participants on site and home safely, and a tremendously successful field course is one in which participants return energized with ideas, some even shifting the direction of their research. Just as the crab's carapace supports diverse adaptations, we have observed during JBL how the experience can significantly influence the research trajectories of early career scientists.

## 3 ESTABLISHING A CULTURE OF MUTUAL RESPECT

Collecting data in $40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and high humidity for multiple days in a row is hard. It can be even harder if the internet connection is limited, you have forgotten a crucial piece of equipment for your experiments, or you have not been able to find any of your species in the field. In the moment, miscommunications occur, and interpersonal conflict is inevitable. Disagreements, of course, are not a sign of dysfunction, but how disagreement is handled is crucial for fostering a creative research environment. A code of conduct, as well as a clear leadership structure proactively outlining expectations of participants well before the course begins, provide a clear through line for conflict resolution and help tackle most interpersonal issues before they arise.

A code of conduct is a document that explicitly states the rules and values of a team or organization, and it includes clear consequences for violating such rules. The JBL uses the Field Code of Conduct developed by the Association of Polar Early Career Scientists (APECS). All participants read and signed the code of conduct before departing for the field site. The values outlined in the document included, but were not limited to, not putting oneself or others in dangerous situations, respecting personal boundaries, and showing respect for the land, its organisms, and the broader Peruvian community (see Supporting Information). For the JBL, we instituted a specific position to mediate issues that may arise. This position, the Outreach and Communications Manager, was the designated person for reporting any breaches of the code of conduct, as they were not directly involved in any of the research projects carried out by the team members. This position had the same gravity and level of leadership as course instructors. With this, the JBL ensured that everyone's well-being was held to the same standard as the science being conducted in the field.

A Survey of Academic Field Experiences (SAFE) has found that harassment, especially of trainees, has historically been more likely to occur during fieldwork [23]. These experiences have a detrimental impact not only on the person's well-being, but also on their future career opportunities [24]. The APECS code of conduct has clear definitions for what constitutes harassment, and a zero-tolerance policy for harassment, as well as an internal leadership structure that provides both on-site and off-site independent contacts to report and initiate actionable consequences for inappropriate behavior. Incorporating principles of respect and inclusion are imperative to empower the next generation of field scientists.

# 4 CHAOS IS A FEATURE, NOT A BUG, BUT IF IT WERE A BUG WE'D STUDY IT 

The modern academic science workflow pressures scientists to publish and to publish quickly. To a behavioral ecologist, identifying lines of scientific research can often feels similar to the "explore/exploit" problems that animals face. Just like an organism needs to balance its time between using the resources readily available (exploit) and looking for new resources for when current supplies dry up (explore), scientists must also balance time between collecting data for lines of questions that are producing publishable results and finding new lines of questions to build a career on. For many career scientists, it can then be difficult to dedicate time purely towards the "explore" process. A field course that focuses on curiosity-driven science emphasizes and provides space for scientists to take a step back and revisit exploration in their scientific approach.

The primary learning activity of JBL is the development of individual projects to be conducted during the course. Individual project planning begins in the months leading up to JBL, during which program leaders and students discuss the students' research interests and develop a preliminary plan for a study organism and necessary equipment to implement the research project. An organism or clade is then selected based on its likelihood of being found at the time of year during which the course takes place, and how it may fit the research interest of the students. Typically projects have focused on invertebreates due to their abundance, diversity, and experimental accessibility. This Krogh principle-forward paradigm emphasizes matching individual projects with organisms whose ecology, physiology, or phylogenetic position best lends itself to answering a fundamental biological question.
"Many years ago when my teacher, Christian Bohr, was interested in the respiratory mechanism of the lung and devised the method of studying the exchange through each lung separately, he found that a certain kind of tortoise possessed a trachea dividing into the main bronchi high up in the neck, and we used to say as a laboratory joke that this animal had been created expressly for the purposes of respiration physiology. I have no doubt that there is quite a number of animals which are similarly "created" for special physiological purposes, but I am afraid that most of them are unknown to the men for whom they were "created," and we must apply to the zoologists to find them and lay our hands on them." -August Krogh ([25])

Following a series of initial pre-program, informal online "lectures" and discussions covering Amazonian biodiversity, and after orientation at the FLP station, students spend the first several days exploring rainforest trails on site to find their proposed study system. As is the case with any field research, initial plans very often fail. Either the proposed study organism becomes difficult to find, proposed experiments do not work out, or limitations with equipment require students to think on their feet, troubleshoot, and devise new plans on the fly. This, however, is not, in our view really a failure. JBL embraces the inherent unpredictability of fieldwork as part of its educational structure. The unmatched biodiversity of the Amazon rainforest ensures there are unlimited other options for conducting a successful research project.

JBL's structure is unique in that it does not hold students to a singular idea or prescribed project outcome, but rather encourages students to embrace the often unpredictable nature of field research. A key

consideration of JBL is to deliberately leave course projects open-ended and to allow the initial ideas from students to grow and change as they gain more on-site experience. This "plan ahead of time, but also plan to fail" approach, which we refer to as "structured spontaneity," left every participant with a successful project in the end, and in many cases, strong pilot data for participants to take back to their institutions. We attribute much of the success of projects to a curiosity-driven approach that encouraged students to make observations, adapt quickly, ask questions, fail again, and revisit the drawing board.

# 5 CURIOSITY DOES NOT OCCUR IN A VACUUM: COLLABORATIONS FOSTER PROBLEM SOLVING 

As collaboration is critical for success in field research, it should be a built-in feature of any field course. Projects undertaken for JBL span a wide breadth (Figure 2), reflecting the diverse applicant selection process. The broad expertise of student selection promotes collaborative interactions among course participants. For instance, a participant with a mechatronics backgrounds may assist in building small-scale experimental arenas for a student with expertise in cellular biology. A participant with expertise in cellular biology may then aid in preparing microscope slides for a behavioral ecologist interested in studying small swimming organisms. That same behavioral ecologist may then help automate and calibrate cameras to study insect flight for another participant. It is critical to the successful implementation and development of course projects to bring together participants and program leaders across disciplines and personal backgrounds to complement one another and bolster creative thinking [26].

For field stations specifically, naturalists offer another layer of collaboration. Natural historians often have a wealth of knowledge from their own personal experience and observations that can spark curiosity for another organismal biologist, and whenever possible, should be included or consulted for any field course. Naturalists often have expertise gained from years of careful observation and insights on how best to find those organisms at the field stations where they work. The observations and knowledge of local flora and fauna can be invaluable to another scientist who studies organisms from a different discipline or perspective. Something as simple as noticing that one group of butterflies - the naturalist would inform you that these are in the family Riodinidae, the metalmarks - likes to land on the underside of leaves can spark curiosity in a biomechanist who studies flight motor control. The observations of naturalists are often difficult to find explicitly declared in the scientific literature. Rather, they often exist in a harder to access ether. Their inclusion in curiosity-driven science is indispensable.

What is a naturalist? Meet naturalist and field guide Jaime Quispe Nina. Born and raised in Puerto Maldonado, Peru, Quispe Nina has been working as a tour guide in the Amazon Rainforest since 2011. Over the past 13 years, he has worked for various companies and more recently for himself, offering guided experiences in South America's jungles. Jaime has worked with scientists and the JBL, offering his extensive knowledge of Peruvian flora and fauna. For the JBL, Quispe Nina helps navigate Peruvian culture and discover diverse organisms in the forest, by sight, smell, touch, and sound in the day, night, and in between.

## 6 CURIOSITY GROWS FROM IN SITU SCIENCE ON THREE LEVELS

The JBL aims to foment curiosity with an in situ approach to a field course. Here we use the term in situ to mean being physically and mentally present in an environment where a course takes place. We believe this is an effective substrate for centering curiosity-driven science as an educational aim. We think that in situ education for scientific field courses is more than showing up to a location for the research itself. To us, in situ requires presence and engagement at three interlocking levels: the environment, the scientific community, and also the greater community where a field site exists.

In situ engagement with the environment signifies understanding field research through the lens of an environmental identity. An environmental identity is something that each person has, whether they know it or not, and is a term used to refer to how we see ourselves in relation to the natural world [27]. For a scientist's environmental identity, they may see the rainforest as a biodiversity hotspot with a new butterfly waiting to be discovered. For a subsistence farmer, the relationship between the rainforest and the person may be more about a day-to-day livelihood. Fieldwork can and should be understood in the social context of the environments where it occurs. In situ engagement with the environment for curiosity-driven science requires understanding biodiversity not just as an experimental tool, but also as a socio-political entity.

In situ within the scientific community reflects understanding, as scientists, a responsibility as mentors and colleagues. Field stations are crossroads for wide-ranging corners of the scientific community from all career stages and disciplines. The same field site may simultaneously be a temporary home to industrial

![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Figure 2. Example of student-developed projects at JBL. A Fluid dynamics of excrement expulsion from a stink bug. B Flight control of upside-down takeoffs from a metalmark butterfly (Riodinidae). C Collective motion from a gregarious caterpillar mass. D Ballistic escape maneuver from a monkey hopper (Eumasticidae). E Dispersal of Massospora sp.-infected cicadas which lose their entire abdomen while alive. F Anatomy of a xylem-sap feeding cicada, which pierces tree bark with its stylus.
engineers, ornithologists, or disease ecologists ranging from the high school to senior faculty levels. The confluence of expertise at field stations is an invaluable opportunity for unexpected collaboration. This especially includes collaborations with Peruvian universities and inclusion of their undergraduates as active participants in field projects. This was an indispensable feature of the JBL, as course projects matured from contributions from scientists with a breadth of expertise and experiences.

In situ at the community level reflects a commitment to being active participants not just in the science but in the local communities where the science takes place. One of the unique aspects of Finca las Piedras as a field station is that it is built in an area that lies between regions with differing levels of environmental regulations, ranging from completely unprotected land zoned for agricultural use to concessions for the sustainable harvest of Brazil nuts from the natural rainforest. Finca las Piedras is also home to The Amazon Lab, a project led by National Geographic Explorer and FLP Director Johana Reyes, that specializes in environmental identity-centered education. This means that, as a field station, FLP is truly part of the local community and has an active role as an educational institution and resource. The potential for community engagement was a major factor in choosing a field site for a field course emphasizing curiosity driven-science. The course structure of JBL was developed with community engagement as a core tenet. Each participant develops outreach programming for age groups ranging from schoolchildren to adults (Figure 3). No single stratum of the three layers of an in situ approach exists alone, and each is indispensable for curiosity-driven science.

# 7 QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DATA IMPROVE FUTURE OUTCOMES 

Both quantitative and qualitative data from participants are crucial in improving and iterating upon any field course. Each, however, presents its own challenges to collect in a meaningful way. Taking a cue from Galileo (through the historian Thomas-Henri Martin), we think of measuring the outcomes of a field course as containing two distinct halves:
"Measure what is measurable..."
Getting data from participants before and after any field course is a first step in measuring the measurable.

![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Figure 3. Example of scientific outreach conducted at JBL.A Local high school student dissecting a monkey-hopper wing using a pair of tweezers to investigate wing folding anatomy. B Students observing spider egg cases under a home-built bright field microscope. C Thermal camera display demonstrates evaporative cooling when water is poured over a student's head. D Elementary school students investigating wind dispersal of dandelion seeds using a Photron high-speed camera.

Designing and implementing a meaningful survey can at first be daunting. After all, many statisticians and educational researchers have dedicated their entire careers to accurately measuring learning outcomes. It should not be expected of a non-specialist in the field to nail this aspect on the first try. There are entire volumes written on the subject [28]. Instead, most universities have specialists in research design who have put in the long hours to master using surveys as a measurement instrument. Some universities may even have centers dedicated to this process altogether. This way, you are more likely to have meaningful data that will allow you to improve any element of a course that did not work as intended and can be immediately addressed. Quantitative metrics of educational efficacy may also be important for future funding opportunities.

For example, the JBL is reviewed by the Georgia Tech Center for Education Integrating Science, Mathematics, and Computing (CEISMC), an independent external evaluator (IRB Number H23323). CEISMC independently developed survey questions to minimize bias. To assess the outcomes of the field research experience, all the participants responded to pre- and post-surveys in which the perceptions of knowledge, skills, and attitudes gained following the program were evaluated, as well as their level of satisfaction with the program elements. Methodologically speaking, quantitative inferences typically require larger sample sizes to make claims regarding the impact of a program. An in situ approach, such as the one used in JBL, warrants exploration into the experiences of program participants. Thus, using multiple data sources can capture perceptions and highlight ways the program was perceived to be effective in its goals, when the number of participants is limited.
"... and make measurable what is not so."
Qualitative data from course participants can be just as valuable as quantitative data, but it often seems difficult to make measurable. Part of our philosophy was to give equal footing to all participants regardless of whether they were a postdoc or an undergraduate. For example, course leadership held open conversations about how to improve the course for the future. Within the culture of mutual respect, undergraduates were able to speak up about how the timing of the course interfered with semester exams at Peruvian universities. Rather than writing this off as a difficulty, we instead changed when the course would occur from the following year onwards so that Peruvian undergraduate participants would not have to compromise

participation in order to study for exams. This improvement to undergraduate access would be difficult to survey quantitatively and was an improvement to the course that came about by providing space for participant voices.

Pre- and post- surveys findings indicate high participant satisfaction with the JBL, positive change in their knowledge of topics related to the program (i.e. conservation issues in the Amazon, field research techniques, and frugal designs), and perceived increased confidence to perform several tasks related to field research. For example, on average, participants reported agreement (using a five-point Likert scale) on the post-survey that they could "prep and complete advanced labs in the field ( $\mathrm{M}=4.33, \mathrm{SD}=0.47$ ), create research that helps me to become immersed in the local culture, landscapes and experiences ( $\mathrm{M}=$ $4.50, \mathrm{SD}=0.50$ ), and design my field research projects to encourage others to be more engaged in their communities" $(\mathrm{M}=4.33, \mathrm{SD}=0.47$ ).

Regarding perceived satisfaction the JBL, participants reported the research experiences were "well organized, responsive to individual needs, and conducted in culturally authentic ways with local participants." Interpersonal interactions and collaboration fostered through the program were perceived as key benefits of participating in the JBL. As one participant stated on an open-response item, "Meeting and getting to collaborate with the other participants was extremely valuable." Another participant described, "... the close connections with scientists from a range of disciplines which will become future collaborators," as a key benefit of the JBL. One participant summarized their overall experience in the JBL,
"Before this, I did not have an idea of what field research entails. After participating in the Jungle Biomechanics Lab, not only do I get to experience the thrill and challenges of doing research in the field, but also met amazing people from all background [sic]. It also changes my perspective on how exciting science can be done outside of lab, but also provide me with a mean to build a program like this to appreciate the biodiversity that nature offers."

Together, these quantitative and qualitative data provide key insights into the participant experience that demonstrate the success and opportunities to further improve the JBL.

# 8 FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES AND WAYS TO PARTICIPATE 

During our annual application call, we often have to deny a significant number of applications due to NSF tax-dollars constraints that require us to fully cover the costs for US students only. Additionally, operating between the US and Peru makes JBL inaccessible to many students worldwide, as highlighted by a tweet on X inquiring about JBL equivalents in India [29]

So what can you do if JBL is inaccessible to you? First, many field stations offer opportunities for research assistants, where room and board are often covered in return for assisting with ongoing research. Field Projects International, for instance, offers structured field courses ranging from conservation science to jungle genomics [30].

Second, faculty can incorporate JBL-like activities in their grants. The genesis of JBL was as part of the Broader Impacts of S.B.'s NSF CAREER proposal [31], which later evolved into a full NSF grant through the IRES program [32]. Foundations such as National Geographic, Moore and Fulbright also offer grant opportunities for education-related activities.

Third, many universities and institutions offer travel grants and scholarships specifically for international field research. Check with your institution's financial aid office or research department for available funding opportunities. Organizations like the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology (SICB) and the Ecological Society of America (ESA) also provide grants and fellowships for students and early-career researchers.

Finally, exploration doesn't have to begin at an exotic field station. Urban jungles, local parks, ponds, zoos, or even your backyard are teeming with opportunities for discovery. Many significant findings began with scientists observing their immediate surroundings, from squirrel acrobatics [33], dog slurping [34], springtail aerodynamics [35], cellular origami [36], cat grooming [37], insect excretion [38], caterpillar electric-sense [39], planthopper gears [40], snapping shrimp [41], firefly flashes [42], elephant trunks [43] and leaping eels [44], to name just a few. Curiosity can start right at home. Today. And right away. The simple pleasure and joy of small discoveries help you develop your observational muscle, laying the groundwork for more extensive field research in the future.

## CONCLUDING REMARKS

The in Situ Jungle Biomechanics Laboratory (JBL) exemplifies how a curiosity-driven approach can be integrated into field science education. By immersing early career researchers in the Amazon rainforest, JBL fosters a unique hands-on interdisciplinary learning experience across the physics of living systems,

biomechanics, and robotics. Guided by the Krogh principle, participants develop critical research skills by matching research questions with 'non-model' organisms [45] that live outside test tubes and petri dishes, thereby maximizing discovery. They engage in collaborative scientific inquiry and gain a deeper understanding of organismal biomechanics within a broader ecological context. Using accessible, opensource, and frugal tools to enable "science under a tree," JBL democratizes scientific research and inspires participants to pursue their endeavors with renewed curiosity and purpose. Reflecting on Eisner's notion of the "exploratory experience" as "a sine qua non for the development of the urge, and as a consequence, the capacity, to make discoveries in nature," JBL embodies this principle by nurturing the exploratory spirit essential for scientific discovery [1].

JBL's emphasis on "structured spontaneity" highlights the value of embracing the inherent unpredictability of fieldwork. This approach fosters resourcefulness and creative thinking "inside the box" of hardware, infrastructure, and time constraints. Practicing a truly in situ philosophy, as opposed to parachute science (dropping into a community, extracting samples, and leaving without community engagement), JBL integrates local naturalists' knowledge and engages with the community, including high school outreach, ensuring that the benefits of scientific research extend beyond academic circles. This two-way exchange enriches both the JBL participants and the community. JBL serves as a launchpad model for other field courses, blending rigorous scientific inquiry with the joy of discovery. As we refine and expand this program, we remain committed to nurturing the curiosity and creativity that lie at the heart of scientific exploration.

As George M. Whitesides [46] aptly observed,
Because following curiosity can seem effortless, it is easy to assume it does not need to be learned, practiced, or encouraged, that it is not important, and that it will somehow take care of itself. But, as with many activities that are competing for time and attention in a utilitarian world, curiosity can atrophy from neglect. It can certainly be unfocused, and lead to nothing (or at least nothing immediately useful), but using it as the starting point for careful observation of nature and society is a nontrivial skill, and a starting point for new intellectual endeavors and adventures. It is one essential contributor to creativity in science, and a start in forcing new ideas into inflexible professional orthodoxies.
What happens to science without it? My students occasionally (for other reasons) ask "What is the one novel I must read?" I answer "1984."

That is a world without curiosity.
Or science.
This sentiment encapsulates the mission of JBL. By fostering curiosity and creativity, we aim to inspire the next generation of scientists to drive exploration and innovation, ensuring that scientific discovery continues to flourish and address the challenges of climate change, species decline, and habitat preservation in this Anthropocene.

abstract:
Field work is an essential component not just for organismal biology, but
also for the expanding umbrella of disciplines which have turned their
attention towards living systems. Observing organisms in naturalistic contexts
is a critical component of discovery; however, conducting field research can be
a massive barrier for scientists who do not have experience working with
organisms in a naturalistic context under challenging field conditions. Here we
propose 8 critical steps for organizing and executing interdisciplinary
curiosity-driven field research, drawing on the insights from The in Situ
Jungle Biomechanics Lab (JBL). The JBL program is a field research course that
helps early-career scientists gain experience in organizing and conducting
interdisciplinary field research. JBL uses a curiosity-driven approach to field
science education by encouraging early-career researchers to explore scientific
questions in the Peruvian Amazon with a non-prescriptive approach to research
output. We achieve an inclusive research space by bringing scientists from
across disciplines together, with local communities to collaborate and spark
new questions and ideas. To stoke curiosity, the JBL imparts a naturalist
tradition set forth by organismal biologists of the 20th century who have
extolled the merits of observing the natural world as a form of scientific
exploration.
